citeinfo.title: Evidence for nonuniform permafrost degradation after fire in boreal landscapes

pubinfo.publish: Journal of Geophysical Research - Earth Surface

descript.abstract: Fire can be a significant driver of permafrost change in boreal landscapes, altering the availability of soil carbon and nutrients that have important implications for future climate and ecological succession. However, not all landscapes are equally susceptible to fire-induced change. As fire frequency is expected to increase in the high latitudes, methods to understand the vulnerability and resilience of different landscapes to permafrost degradation are needed. Geophysical and other field observations reveal details of both near-surface (less than 1 m) and deeper (greater than 1 m) impacts of fire on permafrost along 11 transects that span burned-unburned boundaries in different landscape settings within interior Alaska. Data collected along the 11 transect locations include: electrical resistivity tomography (ERT), downhole nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), active layer thickness (ALT), organic layer thickness (OLT), and plant species cover. These geospatial datasets are the foundation for the journal article, "Evidence for non-uniform permafrost degradation after fire in boreal landscapes", published in the Journal of Geophysical Research - Earth Surface.
descript.purpose: Data were collected to quantify the belowground impacts of fire on permafrost in boreal landscapes.

spdom.descgeog: Interior Alaska, near Fairbanks and southeast along the Alaska Highway towards Canada

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: There is no guarantee concerning the accuracy of the data. Any user who modifies the data is obligated to describe the types of modifications they perform. Data have been checked to ensure the accuracy. If any errors are detected, please notify the originating office. The U.S. Geological Survey strongly recommends that careful attention be paid to the metadata file associated with these data. Acknowledgment of the U.S. Geological Survey would be appreciated in products derived from these data. cntperp.cntorg: USGS - Crustal Geophysics and Geochemistry Science Center

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

method.methdesc: Plant species cover class was visually estimated within undisturbed and disturbed vegetation zones of each transect. Nomenclature for the vegetation zones (e.g. LTER-U) consists of the site name followed by a zone descriptor, where U is unburned, B is burned, D is drainage, F is fireline, and T is thermokarst. Where multiple vegetation zones within each category occurred, the zones were numbered sequentially.

procstep.procdesc: Ocular estimates of vegetation type and abundance were recorded manually in the field, and later digitally transcribed and stored.

enttyp.enttypd: Visual estimates of vegetation type and abundance along transects

attr.attrdef: Ocular estimate of plant species percent cover class

attrdomv.udom: Ocular estimate of plant species percent cover class

attr.attrdef: Plant genus, species, subspecies, and authority names when known, or life form when unknown

attrdomv.udom: Plant genus, species, subspecies, and authority names when known, or life form when unknown
